HB 1357 Sep 1: at 7:15 am during a thick fog, heard a very distinct echo to the whistle from about WNW; altered course to SW by S which brought the echo abeam, & at 7:50 the fog lifted enough to allow us to resume our course; at 9 am it was quite clear & we then saw a berg ~½ mile long & 100 to 120' high, quite flat on top, bearing ENE. We passed ~1 mile S of the berg [actual position calculated]. When the echo was heard we stopped & got a good bearing of it. Marine Observer Vol.9 1932.

HB 1359 Sep 15: Aug 15: 60.30N 48.40W on the voyage from Philadelphia to Ivigtut, met the first ice 30 miles off the coast of Greenland, some scattered ice & bergs, fogs & light winds having prevailed nearly all the way from C.Race to the 59th parallel. Aug 27: this position, obsefved ice & several bergs extending 4 miles off shore to as far as we could see.
